want to share a few things about my experience getting my first job at Century back in
1997 like a lot of you I did a lot of preparation I did mock interviews I read
technical books to get ready um I asked my friends who worked at Accenture what's the hiring process like and I did
my best to be totally prepared for getting that job but there's something
that I've learned now and that's only after interviewing being the interviewer
of hundreds of Engineers for jobs that I did not know back then and that's you
have about five minutes to convince the person who is interviewing you that
you're fit for the job and I know that's not fair because a lot of people think well I have like 45 minutes maybe an
hour for That interview but most hiring managers we have a really good idea of
who we want to hire and more than likely you're not competing against the job
description you're competing against against all the other people who came before you so I've been on hiring Loops
where I'm talking to person number three number four number five but like person
two really wowed me and really you're trying to beat that person that's something we don't say out loud but you
have a very short period of time to convince the hiring manager that you are the right person for the job because
we're humans we naturally try to optimize and there are a few things that you can do though to kind of mitigate
this Factor one is just the simple things that your mother or your father
or someone who raised you said and that's be on time you would be amazed at
how many people are late to interviews it's ridiculous even virtual ones where
all you have to do is literally log on to zoom or to teams or whatever you're using and so the simple practice of just
being on time will at least remove something against you I also give people
the advice and again I wish that I had this advice when I was you know 22 years old trying to get that first tech job is
is be concise because I've had multiple times where as the hiring manager I have
a list of like 10 to 12 questions that I'm trying to get through and I asked
the first question and the candidate spends 10 minutes answering that first
question don't do that you want to give a good answer you should have probably good answers rehearsed and ready ready
to go but you can speak for maybe a minute maybe two minutes and then say do
you have more questions or I can go into more detail because you want to get the hiring manager the opportunity to help
time box the interview because you don't know how many questions they have as the hiring manager I know so you want to do
your part to make sure that you're helping to guide the interview good hiring managers are going to mind the
clock but you can also be a part of that process which gives the hiring manager a really good view of how you work
together uh at work and I'm going to say this a lot over the course of this
presentation when you're talking about your experience and your background
focus on impact not activity so many times when I've been the hiring manager
for a job whether that's at GitHub or Accenture a lot of people when I ask
them a question about tell me about your first project tell me about what you're working on now they give me activity
they describe the team that they're working on they describe the tech stack they describe some of the Milestones but
that's activity that's not impact activity is good but impact is what
we're looking for we're looking for what did you do to improve the the development process what did you do to
make contributions to the way that cult reviews are conducted what impact did you have on your team on your customers
and on the company don't talk about activities or don't just talk about activities it's really important for you
to give a sense of the impact that you had on your teams because I know at
GitHub we hire people to have an impact not just to do
task um I will also say that one thing I'm seeing in the industry is that
companies are beginning to publish the interview questions online and when I was at Health Scout this is something
that I really pushed for because like most companies at help Scout when I was
there we have standard interview questions that we asked for the initial interview for the technical screen for
the other parts of the process and we before I got there these questiones were
very much inside the company meaning that you did not know what the crushes were going to be until you actually were
going through the interview process and again this is fine this works okay but
one thing that I realize is that a number of people who came to interview at help Scout were not native English
speakers and so our questions were all in English but if you have someone who
speaks French or Greek or Italian and English is a second or third language
it's really unfair to them to have the questions in English hidden away because
what happens that often when I who speak English ask the question in English that
person has to hear the question in English translate it mentally to their native tongue think about an answer and
then translate that answer back and I felt that this kind of hiding away of the interview questions was something
that was unfair I also thought about people who were like me where I need processing time if you give me a
question in advance I will give you a really good thoughtful answer if you spring it on me in an interview where
I'm already nervous I'm not going to give as good of an answer so I felt that
putting the questions in public was a way to be more fair you gave non-native
speakers of English the opportunity to read the questions in advance and you gave people who just need time to
process the opportunity to do that processing because I've seen multiple times where you have candidates and one
just needs that processing time and they may be a better candidate but if you don't give them the questions they may
not pop as much as someone who's more suited to like offthe cff answers so
what we did at help Scout and I pushed this was we put our initial screen questions and our technical questions in
a public GitHub repo so that anyone can see before the interview what the
questions are and in the email that HR sends or that recruiting sends when we
schedule the interview we say the questions that we're going to ask are in this public repo now we don't publish
the exact questions that we're going to ask we publish the whole set and the interviewers can pick from you know
probably three or four of those questions so you don't know exactly what you're going to be asked but you get the
set of questions and what I found from doing this is that candidates who
actually take the time to read those questions are better prepared so I'm a big fan of this uh I'm a big fan of
making your interview questions public some people think it's controversial because people think well you're going to get canned responses or people going
to memorize answers but I don't think that that's a valid concern because our questions are meant
to be phrased in a way that you can't memorize the answers right it's not like we're asking technical questions where
there's one right answer our questions are things like tell me a time when you had conflict with a fellow team member
or tell me a time when you disagree with your manager and you were right and your manager was wrong right those are
questions that you really can't memorize the answers to but I bring this up
because if you are interviewing at a company where they published the interview questions you should read
those questions I have several times worked at help Scout where we have the
questions posted in that GitHub repo someone comes to the interview and I ask
like like one of the top three questions on the list and they're like huh that's
a great question like yes I know it's a great question I wrote it and it's been in public and so they they often
struggle to answer this very public question that they should have been um ready to to go with so I will say that
if you are interviewing for a company you want to see do they publish the questions in advance so that's one thing
that uh that I want to share with you the other thing that I wish I would have known getting that first job is that
often most hiring managers when we get done with that state of questions what do we do we ask the candidate do you
have any questions for me you should have questions for the interviewer because that shows that you
you've been thoughtful that shows that hopefully you've done your research that you're not just going on some interview
loop with multiple companies but that you've actually prepare yourself for working at this company so always have
questions prepared you should never say no I don't have any questions and some of the good questions to ask when the
hiring manager asks you do you have any questions is to ask tell me about how
does this role fit into the strategy of the company or you can say who will I
report to will I report to you the person who's asking me these questions or report to someone else um you can
also ask is this role a backfill for someone who's left or is it a new team
that's being spun up and those are really good thoughtful questions they
also give you a lot of insight into what you're walking into if you do get the job now I want to give one more tip
again this is for people who are trying to get that first job you're going through the hiring process and that is
you might get um a job offer from the company right and so the ultimate goal
of a candidate going through interviewing is to get that offer and one thing that again that I did not know

first offer you get is usually not the final offer because there's a lot of calculations that companies go through
when we're coming up with what do we offer this candidate like we like this candidate the hiring committee likes the
candidate we want this person to work here but we have to look at what's their skill set what are we looking for what
uh what part of the country or the world do they work in because most companies you pay based on where you live some

of factors in what we offer so that first offer is usually a bit of a test
to see what you're willing to accept and I'm just again I did not know this for years and so what you want to do is see
that first offer as an indicator and signal that they're interested but don't
assume that that's the best that that that you can get so some of the things that I've done in my career when you get
that first offer is that you want to test it you want to say look you know
this offer which is usually a combination of like salary there's maybe a signing bonus uh if your
company's publicly traded there might be stock rsus uh time off right so I'm
talking total compensation when you get that total compensation offer you want to look at it through the lens of what
you're looking for and if one numbers off let's say salary you can negotiate
you can say you know what this salary is a little bit lower than what I was expecting but can we up the signing

package to send back so that they can talk to their boss about the offer and then what you get back is that you'll

adjustments to the signing bonus or the time off and they'll say ah we we can't
